options.content:
## ðŸš€ Desktop Transformation - Persona Mapping

This dashboard provides a comprehensive overview of **application inventory, usage, and performance** â€” essential data for planning and executing **desktop transformation initiatives**.

Instead of assigning all users full personal virtual machines, you can use this data to:
- Identify which apps are **actually used**
- Understand the **performance impact** of those apps
- Group users with similar needs
- Deliver more **cost-effective, tailored desktop experiences**

---

## ðŸ” Dashboard Structure â€” Each Row Answers a Key Question

1. **What apps are installed?**  
   â†’ View all applications detected across endpoints and virtual machines.

2. **What apps are used?**  
   â†’ Discover which apps are in foreground, how often, and by whom.

3. **How well do these apps perform?**  
   â†’ Examine CPU, RAM, disk, and more metrics per app to gauge ressource consumption.

4. **How are browsers being used?**  
   â†’ Analyze browser usage patterns to find candidates that can be assigned a browser only.

---

## Â©ï¸ Credits

- Thanks to [Matthew Greenbaum](https://www.linkedin.com/in/matthew-greenbaum) for the idea for the **App importance** chart.

---

> ðŸ’¡ Use filters at the top to narrow down by machine, app name, user, or time range.  
> This dashboard helps you match **application needs to user personas**, and transition from "one size fits all" desktops to **right-sized solutions**.

panels.description: The total number of times any app appears across all devices
panels.title: Total app installations

targets.query:
Application_ApplicationInventory
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| summarize install_count = count_distinct(Host) by DisplayName
| top 10 by install_count desc

Application_ApplicationInventory
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| summarize install_count = count_distinct(Host) by Publisher
| top 10 by install_count desc

Application_ApplicationInventory
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| summarize 
by Host, App = DisplayName, Version = DisplayVersion, Publisher = Publisher, Install_date = InstallDate, Install_location = InstallLocation
| sort by Host asc, App asc, Version asc

options.content:
## App importance
The chart **App importance** below shows which applications contribute most to your organizationâ€™s productivity or system load, so you can focus on the handful that matter.

**Key drivers of importance:**  
 - **User engagement:** How long and how often people actively use an app.
 - **Resource impact:** How much CPU work an app does, even when running in the background.

You can use the dashboard variable **App importance usage weight** to manipulate the weights.

**X-axis (Rank):**  
  - Apps sorted from highest to lowest importance.

**Y-axis (Cumulative %):**  
  - How much of the total importance has been covered once you include apps up to that rankâ€”showing the â€œfew apps, big impactâ€ effect.

## App foreground usage over time  
This chart shows how much your users are actively working in applications across the selected period. It helps you:

- **Spot overall trends:** See if engagement is growing, stable, or declining over days/weeks.  
- **Identify daily rhythms:** Notice repeatable peaks during core work hours and dips during off-hours or weekends.  
- **Detect anomalies:** Sudden surges or drops may signal new feature rollouts, system issues, or company events.  
- **Plan proactively:** Use long-term patterns to forecast capacity needs, schedule maintenance, or target user training when engagement lags.

Keep an eye on this chart to understand when your team is most productive and to catch unexpected shifts in usage early.

targets.query:
Session_SessionDetail
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| where SessionFgProcessName != ""
| summarize Count = count() by bin(Timestamp, $time_agg), SessionFgAppId
| evaluate pivot(SessionFgAppId, sum(Count))
| sort by Timestamp

panels.description:
Lists all versions, users and computers by app, whether in foreground or not. Columns can be filtered.

Click on an app to filter the charts below.

targets.query:
Process_ProcessDetail
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| where AppId !in ("Microsoft Windows OS","MsWnOS","macOS") 
| where ProcUser !in ("sys","nvc","lvc")
| where AppId has "$App"
| summarize 
Versions = count_distinct(AppVersion),
Users = count_distinct(ProcUser),
Hosts = count_distinct(Host)
by App = AppId
| sort by App asc

panels.title: App usage data table

targets.query:
Process_ProcessDetail
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| where SessionID > 0
| where AppId !in~ ("Microsoft Windows OS","MsWnOS","macOS") 
| where ProcUser !in~ ("sys","nvc","lvc")
| where AppId has "$App"
| summarize usage = count_distinct(ProcUser) by bin(Timestamp, $time_agg), AppId
| evaluate pivot(AppId, max(usage))

panels.description: Select an app in the data table above to filter this chart.

targets.query:
Process_ProcessDetail
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| where AppId !in ("Microsoft Windows OS","MsWnOS","macOS") 
| where ProcUser !in ("sys","nvc","lvc")
| where AppId has "$App"
| summarize 
by App = AppId, Version = AppVersion, User = ProcUser, Machine = Host
| sort by App asc, Version asc, User asc

panels.title: Usage detail

options.content: App performance is part of the **Troubleshooting Poor User Experience** dashboard. You can access it via the link below.

panels.description: Shows all users who had a browser in foreground more than ${browser_usage_threshold}% of the time. The threshold can be set at the dashboard's top.

targets.query:
Session_SessionDetail
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| summarize 
count_fg_app = count()
by SessionFgProcessName, SessionUser
| join kind=inner (
    Session_SessionDetail
    | summarize event_count = count() by SessionUser
) on SessionUser
| extend app_in_foreground_percent = round( todouble(count_fg_app) / todouble(event_count) * 100, 1 )
| where SessionFgProcessName in~ ("chrome.exe","msedge.exe","firefox.exe","iexplore.exe","CitrixEnterpriseBrowser.exe")
| where app_in_foreground_percent >= $browser_usage_threshold
| project user = SessionUser, browser = SessionFgProcessName, foreground = app_in_foreground_percent

panels.title: Browser in foreground >= ${browser_usage_threshold}%

panels.description: If the foreground window is a browser: the URL of the active tab.

targets.query:
Session_SessionDetail
| where $__timeFilter(Timestamp)
| where SessionFgBrowserActiveTabHost != ""
| summarize 
count = count()
by web_app = SessionFgBrowserActiveTabHost
| sort by count desc

panels.title: Used web apps

list.description: Filter the dashboard to usernames or parts of username. I.e. "jo" would include the users "joe" and "john".
list.name: User

list.description: Filter the dashboard to computer names or parts of computer names. I.e. "pc" would include the computers "pc1" and "pc-test".
list.label: Machine
list.name: Computer

list.description:
Filter the dashboard to an app or parts of app names. I.e. "my" would include the apps "my-dev-app" and "my-hr-app".

Note that app names may differ for inventory, usage, and foreground usage, as uberAgent's source in the operating system differs. While an app can be named "Vendor MyApp" in inventory, it may be named just "MyApp" when in foreground. Hence, use this filter with caution.
list.name: App

list.description:
Foregroundâ€usage weight in decimal notation (0.0â€“1.0).

Example: 0.8 means 80% emphasis on app foreground usage; the rest (100-80=20%) represents the CPUâ€usage weight.
list.label: App importance usage weight
list.name: app_imp_usage
